components.title: Configure Nuxt component auto-registration.
components.description: Any components in the directories configured here can be used throughout your pages, layouts (and other components) without needing to explicitly import them.

imports.title: Configure how Nuxt auto-imports composables into your application.

dirs.title: An array of custom directories that will be auto-imported. Note that this option will not override the default directories (~/composables, ~/utils).

pages.title: Whether to use the vue-router integration in Nuxt 3. If you do not provide a value it will be enabled if you have a `pages/` directory in your source folder.

compilerOptions.title: Options for the Vue compiler that will be passed at build time.

baseURL.title: The base path of your Nuxt application.
baseURL.description: This can be set at runtime by setting the NUXT_APP_BASE_URL environment variable.

buildAssetsDir.title: The folder name for the built site assets, relative to `baseURL` (or `cdnURL` if set). This is set at build time and should not be customized at runtime.

cdnURL.title: An absolute URL to serve the public folder from (production-only).
cdnURL.description: This can be set to a different value at runtime by setting the `NUXT_APP_CDN_URL` environment variable.

head.title: Set default configuration for `<head>` on every page.

layoutTransition.title: Default values for layout transitions.
layoutTransition.description: This can be overridden with `definePageMeta` on an individual page. Only JSON-serializable values are allowed.

pageTransition.title: Default values for page transitions.
pageTransition.description: This can be overridden with `definePageMeta` on an individual page. Only JSON-serializable values are allowed.

keepalive.title: Default values for KeepAlive configuration between pages.
keepalive.description: This can be overridden with `definePageMeta` on an individual page. Only JSON-serializable values are allowed.

plugins.title: An array of nuxt app plugins.
plugins.description:
Each plugin can be a string (which can be an absolute or relative path to a file). If it ends with `.client` or `.server` then it will be automatically loaded only in the appropriate context.
It can also be an object with `src` and `mode` keys.
tags:
@example
```js
plugins: [
  '~/plugins/foo.client.js', // only in client side
  '~/plugins/bar.server.js', // only in server side
  '~/plugins/baz.js', // both client & server
  { src: '~/plugins/both-sides.js' },
  { src: '~/plugins/client-only.js', mode: 'client' }, // only on client side
  { src: '~/plugins/server-only.js', mode: 'server' } // only on server side
]
```

css.title: You can define the CSS files/modules/libraries you want to set globally (included in every page).
css.description: Nuxt will automatically guess the file type by its extension and use the appropriate pre-processor. You will still need to install the required loader if you need to use them.

builder.title: The builder to use for bundling the Vue part of your application.

transpile.title: If you want to transpile specific dependencies with Babel, you can add them here. Each item in transpile can be a package name, a function, a string or regex object matching the dependency's file name.
transpile.description: You can also use a function to conditionally transpile. The function will receive an object ({ isDev, isServer, isClient, isModern, isLegacy }).
transpile.tsType: Array<string | RegExp | ((ctx: { isClient?: boolean; isServer?: boolean; isDev: boolean }) => string | RegExp | false)>

templates.title: You can provide your own templates which will be rendered based on Nuxt configuration. This feature is specially useful for using with modules.

analyze.title: Nuxt uses `webpack-bundle-analyzer` to visualize your bundles and how to optimize them.
analyze.description: Set to `true` to enable bundle analysis, or pass an object with options: [for webpack](https://github.com/webpack-contrib/webpack-bundle-analyzer#options-for-plugin) or [for vite](https://github.com/btd/rollup-plugin-visualizer#options).

extends.title: Extend project from multiple local or remote sources.
extends.description:
Value should be either a string or array of strings pointing to source directories or config path relative to current config.
You can use `github:`, `gitlab:`, `bitbucket:` or `https://` to extend from a remote git repository.

theme.title: Extend project from a local or remote source.
theme.description:
Value should be a string pointing to source directory or config path relative to current config.
You can use `github:`, `gitlab:`, `bitbucket:` or `https://` to extend from a remote git repository.

rootDir.title: Define the root directory of your application.
rootDir.description:
This property can be overwritten (for example, running `nuxt ./my-app/` will set the `rootDir` to the absolute path of `./my-app/` from the current/working directory.
It is normally not needed to configure this option.

workspaceDir.title: Define the workspace directory of your application.
workspaceDir.description:
Often this is used when in a monorepo setup. Nuxt will attempt to detect your workspace directory automatically, but you can override it here.
It is normally not needed to configure this option.

srcDir.title: Define the source directory of your Nuxt application.
srcDir.description: If a relative path is specified, it will be relative to the `rootDir`.
tags:
@example
```js
export default {
  srcDir: 'src/'
}
```
This would work with the following folder structure:
```bash
-| app/
---| node_modules/
---| nuxt.config.js
---| package.json
---| src/
------| assets/
------| components/
------| layouts/
------| middleware/
------| pages/
------| plugins/
------| static/
------| store/
------| server/
```

serverDir.title: Define the server directory of your Nuxt application, where Nitro routes, middleware and plugins are kept.
serverDir.description: If a relative path is specified, it will be relative to your `rootDir`.

buildDir.title: Define the directory where your built Nuxt files will be placed.
buildDir.description: Many tools assume that `.nuxt` is a hidden directory (because it starts with a `.`). If that is a problem, you can use this option to prevent that.

modulesDir.title: Used to set the modules directories for path resolving (for example, webpack's `resolveLoading`, `nodeExternals` and `postcss`).
modulesDir.description:
The configuration path is relative to `options.rootDir` (default is current working directory).
Setting this field may be necessary if your project is organized as a yarn workspace-styled mono-repository.

dev.title: Whether Nuxt is running in development mode.
dev.description: Normally, you should not need to set this.

test.title: Whether your app is being unit tested.

debug.title: Set to `true` to enable debug mode.
debug.description: At the moment, it prints out hook names and timings on the server, and logs hook arguments as well in the browser.

ssr.title: Whether to enable rendering of HTML - either dynamically (in server mode) or at generate time. If set to `false` generated pages will have no content.

modules.title: Modules are Nuxt extensions which can extend its core functionality and add endless integrations.
modules.description:
Each module is either a string (which can refer to a package, or be a path to a file), a tuple with the module as first string and the options as a second object, or an inline module function.
Nuxt tries to resolve each item in the modules array using node require path (in `node_modules`) and then will be resolved from project `srcDir` if `~` alias is used.
tags: @note Modules are executed sequentially so the order is important.
modules.tsType: (typeof import('../src/types/module').NuxtModule | string | [typeof import('../src/types/module').NuxtModule | string, Record<string, any>])[]

dir.title: Customize default directory structure used by Nuxt.
dir.description: It is better to stick with defaults unless needed.

assets.title: The assets directory (aliased as `~assets` in your build).

layouts.title: The layouts directory, each file of which will be auto-registered as a Nuxt layout.

middleware.title: The middleware directory, each file of which will be auto-registered as a Nuxt middleware.

pages.title: The directory which will be processed to auto-generate your application page routes.

plugins.title: The plugins directory, each file of which will be auto-registered as a Nuxt plugin.

public.title: The directory containing your static files, which will be directly accessible via the Nuxt server and copied across into your `dist` folder when your app is generated.

extensions.title: The extensions that should be resolved by the Nuxt resolver.

alias.title: You can improve your DX by defining additional aliases to access custom directories within your JavaScript and CSS.
tags:
@note Within a webpack context (image sources, CSS - but not JavaScript) you _must_ access
your alias by prefixing it with `~`.

ignoreOptions.title: Pass options directly to `node-ignore` (which is used by Nuxt to ignore files).

ignorePrefix.title: Any file in `pages/`, `layouts/`, `middleware/` or `store/` will be ignored during building if its filename starts with the prefix specified by `ignorePrefix`.

ignore.title: More customizable than `ignorePrefix`: all files matching glob patterns specified inside the `ignore` array will be ignored in building.

watchers.title: The watchers property lets you overwrite watchers configuration in your `nuxt.config`.

rewatchOnRawEvents.title: An array of event types, which, when received, will cause the watcher to restart.

hooks.title: Hooks are listeners to Nuxt events that are typically used in modules, but are also available in `nuxt.config`.
hooks.description:
Internally, hooks follow a naming pattern using colons (e.g., build:done).
For ease of configuration, you can also structure them as an hierarchical object in `nuxt.config` (as below).

runtimeConfig.title: Runtime config allows passing dynamic config and environment variables to the Nuxt app context.
runtimeConfig.description:
The value of this object is accessible from server only using `useRuntimeConfig`.
It mainly should hold _private_ configuration which is not exposed on the frontend. This could include a reference to your API secret tokens.
Anything under `public` and `app` will be exposed to the frontend as well.
Values are automatically replaced by matching env variables at runtime, e.g. setting an environment variable `NUXT_API_KEY=my-api-key NUXT_PUBLIC_BASE_URL=/foo/` would overwrite the two values in the example below.

appConfig.title: Additional app configuration
appConfig.description: For programmatic usage and type support, you can directly provide app config with this option. It will be merged with `app.config` file as default value.

https.title: Whether to enable HTTPS.

url.title: Listening dev server URL.
url.description: This should not be set directly as it will always be overridden by the dev server with the full URL (for module and internal use).

asyncEntry.title: Set to true to generate an async entry point for the Vue bundle (for module federation support).

treeshakeClientOnly.title: Tree shakes contents of client-only components from server bundle.

emitRouteChunkError.title: Emit `app:chunkError` hook when there is an error loading vite/webpack chunks.
emitRouteChunkError.description: You can set this to `reload` to perform a hard reload of the new route when a chunk fails to load when navigating to a new route.

viteNode.title: Use vite-node for on-demand server chunk loading

viteServerDynamicImports.title: Split server bundle into multiple chunks and dynamically import them.

inlineSSRStyles.title: Inline styles when rendering HTML (currently vite only).
inlineSSRStyles.description: You can also pass a function that receives the path of a Vue component and returns a boolean indicating whether to inline the styles for that component.

noScripts.title: Turn off rendering of Nuxt scripts and JS resource hints.

payloadExtraction.title: When this option is enabled (by default) payload of pages generated with `nuxt generate` are extracted

crossOriginPrefetch.title: Enable cross-origin prefetch using the Speculation Rules API.

writeEarlyHints.title: Write early hints when using node server.
tags: @note nginx does not support 103 Early hints in the current version.

componentIslands.title: Experimental component islands support with <NuxtIsland> and .island.vue files.

routes.title: The routes to generate.
routes.description:
If you are using the crawler, this will be only the starting point for route generation. This is often necessary when using dynamic routes.
It is preferred to use `nitro.prerender.routes`.

exclude.title: This option is no longer used. Instead, use `nitro.prerender.ignore`.

routeRules.title: Global route options applied to matching server routes.
tags: @experimental This is an experimental feature and API may change in the future.

serverHandlers.title: Nitro server handlers.
serverHandlers.description: Each handler accepts the following options: - handler: The path to the file defining the handler. - route: The route under which the handler is available. This follows the conventions of https://github.com/unjs/radix3. - method: The HTTP method of requests that should be handled. - middleware: Specifies whether it is a middleware handler. - lazy: Specifies whether to use lazy loading to import the handler.
tags: @note Files from `server/api`, `server/middleware` and `server/routes` will be automatically registered by Nuxt.

options.title: Additional options passed to `vue-router`.
options.description:
Note: Only JSON serializable options should be passed by nuxt config.
For more control, you can use `app/router.options.ts` file.

strict.title: TypeScript comes with certain checks to give you more safety and analysis of your program. Once youâ€™ve converted your codebase to TypeScript, you can start enabling these checks for greater safety. [Read More](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/migrating-from-javascript.html#getting-stricter-checks)

includeWorkspace.title: Include parent workspace in the Nuxt project. Mostly useful for themes and module authors.

typeCheck.title: Enable build-time type checking.
typeCheck.description: If set to true, this will type check in development. You can restrict this to build-time type checking by setting it to `build`. Requires to install `typescript` and `vue-tsc` as dev dependencies.

tsConfig.title: You can extend generated `.nuxt/tsconfig.json` using this option.

shim.title: Generate a `*.vue` shim.
shim.description: We recommend instead either enabling [**Take Over Mode**](https://vuejs.org/guide/typescript/overview.html#volar-takeover-mode) or adding TypeScript Vue Plugin (Volar)** ðŸ‘‰ [[Download](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Vue.vscode-typescript-vue-plugin)].

vite.title: Configuration that will be passed directly to Vite.
vite.description: See https://vitejs.dev/config for more information. Please note that not all vite options are supported in Nuxt.

analyze.title: Nuxt uses `webpack-bundle-analyzer` to visualize your bundles and how to optimize them.
analyze.description: Set to `true` to enable bundle analysis, or pass an object with options: [for webpack](https://github.com/webpack-contrib/webpack-bundle-analyzer#options-for-plugin) or [for vite](https://github.com/btd/rollup-plugin-visualizer#options).

profile.title: Enable the profiler in webpackbar.
profile.description: It is normally enabled by CLI argument `--profile`.

extractCSS.title: Enables Common CSS Extraction using [Vue Server Renderer guidelines](https://ssr.vuejs.org/guide/css.html).
extractCSS.description: Using [extract-css-chunks-webpack-plugin](https://github.com/faceyspacey/extract-css-chunks-webpack-plugin/) under the hood, your CSS will be extracted into separate files, usually one per component. This allows caching your CSS and JavaScript separately and is worth trying if you have a lot of global or shared CSS.
tags:
If you want to extract all your CSS to a single file, there is a workaround for this.
However, note that it is not recommended to extract everything into a single file.
Extracting into multiple CSS files is better for caching and preload isolation. It
can also improve page performance by downloading and resolving only those resources
that are needed.

cssSourceMap.title: Enables CSS source map support (defaults to `true` in development).

serverURLPolyfill.title: The polyfill library to load to provide URL and URLSearchParams.

filenames.title: Customize bundle filenames.
filenames.description: To understand a bit more about the use of manifests, take a look at [this webpack documentation](https://webpack.js.org/guides/code-splitting/).
tags:
@note Be careful when using non-hashed based filenames in production
as most browsers will cache the asset and not detect the changes on first load.
This example changes fancy chunk names to numerical ids:

loaders.title: Customize the options of Nuxt's integrated webpack loaders.

plugins.title: Add webpack plugins.

terser.title: Terser plugin options.
terser.description: Set to false to disable this plugin, or pass an object of options.
tags:
@note Enabling sourceMap will leave `//# sourceMappingURL` linking comment at
the end of each output file if webpack `config.devtool` is set to `source-map`.

aggressiveCodeRemoval.title: Hard-replaces `typeof process`, `typeof window` and `typeof document` to tree-shake bundle.

optimizeCSS.title: OptimizeCSSAssets plugin options.
optimizeCSS.description: Defaults to true when `extractCSS` is enabled.

minimize.title: Set minimize to `false` to disable all minimizers. (It is disabled in development by default).

minimizer.title: You can set minimizer to a customized array of plugins.

postcss.title: Customize PostCSS Loader. Same options as https://github.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader#options

friendlyErrors.title: Set to `false` to disable the overlay provided by [FriendlyErrorsWebpackPlugin](https://github.com/nuxt/friendly-errors-webpack-plugin).
